Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Novel biomimetic materials for water purification: perchlorate treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1336620
Julie Zilles & Charles Werth
University of Illinois Urbana Champaign

New technologies are needed to remove emerging contaminants such as pharmaceuticals, personal care products, and endocrine-disrupting compounds from water. While these contaminants have a wide range of sources, chemical structures, and effects, they share the properties of being toxic even at low concentrations and of being biologically recognized. This project will harness the high specificity, affinity, and activity of biological enzymes to develop novel materials, referred to as biocatalysts, to degrade the drinking water contaminant perchlorate. The enzymes will be tested in two forms: free in solution and encapsulated in hollow lipid spheres or vesicles. Encapsulation in vesicles is expected to increase stability but also to introduce diffusion limitations. The first objective is therefore to measure fundamental properties of these materials: diffusion limitations, reaction rates, and longevity. These data will identify what properties are most likely to limit the utility of the material, providing a focus for subsequent research and data for an initial assessment of the economic feasibility and environmental impacts. Other project objectives will target the limiting properties for improvement using a two-step process of mining biology and applying directed evolution. The first step, mining biology, will consist of screening existing enzyme variants from different microorganisms to identify those with the most suitable combination of properties. In the second step, directed evolution will be used to further improve the best existing enzymes. This approach involves iterative cycles of making random mutations and selecting for those mutant enzymes that show improvements in the desired property. In parallel with these objectives, the project will compare the sustainability of biocatalytic materials for perchlorate reduction to existing and emerging perchlorate treatment options. This sustainability analyses will incorporate economic and environmental impacts in life cycle analysis using both the initial properties and the improved properties obtained in later objectives. The results of the ongoing sustainability analyses will guide the development of these materials and will provide a more general assessment of the potential of biocatalytic materials for water treatment.

This project will contribute to safe drinking water through the development of perchlorate treatment technologies that are effective and efficient. By incorporating evaluation of the potential economic and environmental impacts at an early stage, this research will emphasize development of sustainable water treatment processes. More generally, the insight into factors limiting activity of biocatalytic materials gained here will demonstrate the potential and limitations of this approach, which could provide a highly specific and sensitive means of dealing with emerging contaminants and facilitating water reuse. This work will also contribute to the interdisciplinary education of undergraduate and graduate students in microbiology and engineering, and promote diversity in science and engineering through middle school and high school outreach including under-represented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Novel biomimetic materials for water purification: perchlorate treatment

This project investigated a new technology for the removal of contaminants from drinking water The technology was biocatalysis: use of biological enzymes to remove and detoxify contaminants. The target contaminants, such as pharmaceuticals and endocrine-disrupting compounds, have human health effects at low concentrations and are present in drinking water sources. Perchlorate was our model contaminant; it causes stunted growth and mental retardation in fetuses and young children and hypothyroidism in adults. Biocatalysis can degrade perchlorate in an ideal laboratory system, but its effectiveness in real drinking water sources and its costs and environmental impacts relative to other treatment options had not been tested previously. As detailed below, the project results strongly support the potential of this new approach to water treatment.

The biocatalysts showed high removal activity in real groundwater sources and were active over the full range of temperatures, pHs, and water chemistries expected in real-world applications. These results were used to calibrate a mathematical model, allowing prediction of the activity under different conditions. To improve the performance of the technology, biocatalysts derived from different organisms were compared and the one most appropriate for our intended application was identified. This biocatalyst was seven-fold less susceptible to inactivation, while retaining high activity and affinity for the contaminant.

To compare the costs and environmental impacts of this technology to other treatment options, we modeled five different ways of removing perchlorate from drinking water: non-selective ion exchange, selective ion exchange, biological removal, chemical catalysis, and biocatalysis. As expected, in its current, undeveloped state, biocatalysis was the most expensive option, about one order of magnitude more expensive than those technologies in current use. This was a promising result, as substantial cost savings are expected as a process is scaled up and widely deployed. To guide development of the biocatalytic technology, we conducted sensitivity analyses and compared results computed with different assumptions about development of the technology. This analysis suggests that the biocatalytic approach can be competitive in costs if two targets are met. One target is that the treatment process must allow the biocatalysts to be retained or recovered for reuse. The second target is that the reducing power must be efficiently supplied. In comparison to ion-exchange processes, biocatalysis has the advantage of completely detoxifying perchlorate, rather than just removing it from the water.

One additional direction that arose during this work was the possibility of combining ion exchange and biocatalysis for perchlorate treatment. A hybrid process could prevent perchlorate from being released back into the environment after being removed from drinking water by ion exchange. To investigate the feasibility of such an approach, we added experimental work testing the perchlorate-removal activity of the biocatalysts in ion exchange waste brines. To further improve the sustainability of ion exchange, we also investigated the potential for biocatalytic nitrate removal, which could allow reuse of the ion exchange brine. In both cases the results were promising and provide a basis for design and testing of potential hybrid ion exchange-biocatalytic processes.

This project provided interdisciplinary training in environmental engineering and microbiology to five undergraduate students, four MS students, and one PhD student. The PhD student also participated in the NSF INTERN program, working with pilot- and full-scale biological drinking water treatment processes. Through this program, he gained valuable operational experience and learned about the regulatory processes for approving new drinking water treatment technologies. Modules on physical, chemical and biological principles of drinking and wastewater treatment and clean energy technologies were developed for grade levels 9-12 and presented in Integrated Physical Science and AP Environmental Science courses. The modules were also presented to high school science teachers at an educational conference held by the National Science Teachers Association.

Overall this project has demonstrated the potential of applying biocatalysts for water treatment and identified specific and achievable technology development targets. Biocatalysis provides a new toolbox for environmental engineers to remove emerging contaminants, improving our ability to supply safe drinking water, protect the environment, and facilitate water reuse.
